title: At One's End
content:

++++ NOTICE FROM THE FOUNDATION RECORDS AND INFORMATION SECURITY ADMINISTRATION 

The following file was found in the bedroom of the late Dr Markus Clockwork (O5-1 from 1980-2015) just 5 days after his unfortunate heart attack. The proper origin of the poem contained in this file is unknown. 

-- Maria Jones, Director, RAISA
[[/=]]
[[/div]]

= Upon this dreary night he strode
= A traveller towards his goal.
= The snow of the end crumbled beneath his boots.

= His breath slammed against his skin.
= The breeze tried to fight him.
= But the traveller was determined ever still.

= He sighed and stared up at the monstrous tower in front of him.
= It stood out in the wasteland they had once called "America".
= Watching over the dead land,
= The only remaining visage of a long dead council.

= The traveller kicked down the steel wall that was once a door.
= It crashed to the ground.
= The sound echoed across the dead world.

= He trudged through the reddened halls.
= Blood still dripped from the ceiling,
= Hundreds of years after the end of the world.
= Hundreds of years after the extinction.

= The traveller ran his hands through his white hair.
= The seemed to creak upon touch.
= He groaned.
= He was an anomaly.

= The traveller entered the ballroom.
= The chandelier shuddered with each step.
= Threatening to fall.
= Threatening to fail.
= Threatening to kill.

= The traveller grunted as he pushed away the rubble.
= The area was desolate.
= The grey sterile walls barely holding up.
= He ran his hand along the floor.
= He knew what he was looking for,
= And he knew he was close.

= He jumped down.
= His feet landed on the only grass that remained.
= The bottom of the once mighty site was jarringly untouched.
= It was filled with grass and trees. 
= It was filled with artificial life.
= It was filled with falsehoods.

= The traveller wandered to the spire that was the central database. 
= He typed manically into the system.
= Within seconds the site was aflush with purple light.
= The traveller smiled as the memories came flooding back.

= Every order,
= Every death,
= Every failure,
= Every mission,
= Every meeting,
= Every friend,
= Every sacrifice,
= Every time they called out for him.

= O5-1 lay on the ground as the alarm blared.
= He had done it.
= The world was resetting.
= He would soon cease to exist.
= He sighed with as much pain as relief.
= He looked into the fa√ßade of a sky.
= The traveller smiled.

= And as the world turned to white,
= O5-1 closed his eyes with a smile.
= He could finally rest.
= He could finally die.
